title: 112_hr3117
content: The Act is titled the "Permanent Electronic Duck Stamp Act of 2012" and includes definitions. The "Permanent Electronic Duck Stamp Act of 2012" defines terms such as "actual stamp" as a paper Federal migratory-bird hunting stamp and "automated licensing system" as an electronic system used by State fish and wildlife agencies for issuing licenses. The term "electronic stamp" refers to a unique identifier issued to individuals, printable on paper or electronically, and issued through a State automated licensing system authorized by the Secretary under the Act. It must be compatible with the State's hunting licensing system. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior may authorize States to issue electronic stamps in consultation with State management agencies. The Secretary may authorize States to issue electronic stamps after receiving and approving an application that includes details on the stamp format, fees, and accounting processes. The number of new States participating in the program per year is determined by the Secretary. The Secretary authorizes States to issue electronic stamps by approving applications detailing stamp format, fees, and accounting. States must transfer collected amounts to the Secretary, transmit stamp data electronically, deliver actual stamps, issue duplicates, and provide required policies and information. The Secretary publishes deadlines and eligibility requirements for application submission. The Secretary authorizes States to issue electronic stamps by approving applications detailing stamp format, fees, and accounting. States must transfer collected amounts to the Secretary, transmit stamp data electronically, deliver actual stamps, issue duplicates, and provide required policies and information. The Secretary publishes deadlines, eligibility requirements, and criteria for approving applications. SEC. 5. STATE OBLIGATIONS AND AUTHORITIES. The Secretary requires individuals purchasing electronic stamps to receive an actual stamp before it expires. States must collect and submit customer information and stamp sales data to the Secretary. The Secretary requires states selling electronic stamps to submit sales data and customer information. States can charge a fee for issuing electronic stamps to cover costs. A State authorized to issue electronic stamps may issue a duplicate electronic stamp to replace a lost or damaged one. States cannot require the purchase of a hunting license to obtain an electronic stamp under this Act. SEC. 6. ELECTRONIC STAMP REQUIREMENTS; RECOGNITION OF ELECTRONIC STAMP. The Secretary shall require an electronic stamp issued by a State to have the same format as any other license and specify identifying features of the licensee. The electronic stamp bestows the same privileges as an actual stamp, is recognized nationally as a valid Federal migratory bird hunting stamp, and authorizes the licensee to hunt migratory waterfowl. An electronic stamp issued by a State allows the licensee to hunt migratory waterfowl in any State following its hunting laws. The stamp's duration, agreed upon by the State and the Secretary, cannot exceed 45 days. The authority of a State to issue electronic stamps under this Act may be terminated by the Secretary if the State violates the terms approved by the Secretary, or by the State itself with written notice to the Secretary.
